text.b: I N C O R P O R A T E D

page.text: Proposed wall mounted sign area: 18 sf
(sign is outlined as a single contiguous area and the
Note: sign area does not include any additional area
beyond the letters as the pin mounted acrylic letters
are mounted directly to the building siding which is
not designed to be an integral part of the sign
The purpose of this document is to provide recommendations to the property owner
and facility manager to properly maintain the facility in such a manner that it will
continue to protect the natural resources in the vicinity. This parcel [159 Merrow Road]
is partially located within the Town of Tolland Aquifer Protection Area and abuts a large
wetland corridor that drains to the Tolland Marsh.
The Savings Institute Bank & Trust facility is located upgradient of a wetland and
the site collects runoff from Rte 195. All rainwater that runs-off the bituminous
surfaces will drain to the stormwater management systems, and after treatment,
will discharge to the inland wetlands. The on-site stormwater management
systems are designed to treat the stormwater in accordance with Best
Management Practices [BMP’s] before it reaches the wetlands and to prevent an
increase in peak rates of stormwater runoff from this site.
The first component, located to the south of the access to the drive-thru window,
is a low-mow grass lined swale. The swale shall be inspected on a semi-annual
basis consisting of mowing and removal of any accumulated sediment.
The second component, a sediment forebay, is the westerly portion of the
northerly stormwater wetland and the southerly portion of the easterly stormwater
wetland. The forebays shall be inspected semi-annually and sediment shall be
removed with a backhoe every five years or when sediment has accumulated to
within one-foot of the top of the forebay.
The third component is the stormwater wetlands. Stormwater wetlands are
shallow depressions designed to retain water below its outlet. These two areas are
designed to retain groundwater and should require minimal maintenance as shown
in the Operations and Maintenance Schedule on the following page.
The final component is an underground infiltration system collecting stormwater
from the building rooftop. This system is located in the grass/landscaped area to
the southwest of the building. Inspection ports are provided at the end of each
Fertilization of lawn areas is not required in the Low Mow area, and in the grass
swale or on slope areas. Otherwise, lawn areas shall be fertilized per the
Rate for year 2 lbs. per 1000 sf
The following details the inspection and maintenance requirements and tasks for the
The site owner shall contact Gardner & Peterson Associates with any questions.
Maintain grass at a height of 4 to
or before sediment is within one-
foot of the top of the forebay.
and remove when pool volume is

page.text: Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc. (VHB) has been retained by Simon Konover
Development Corporation to conduct a traffic impact and access study documenting
the potential traffic impacts associated with the construction of a proposed bank in
Tolland, Connecticut. The traffic impact study quantifies both the existing traffic
conditions along area roadways surrounding the site and the projected future traffic
conditions expected with and without the proposed development of the site. This
document provides a detailed description of the study methodology, analysis, and
The proposed development site is an approximately 6.1-acre vacant parcel located on
Route 195 (Merrow Road) 0.1 miles east of I-84 in Tolland, Connecticut. Based on
current plans, the proposed site development will consist of the construction of a
Access to the site will be provided via a privately owned full-access driveway on
Merrow Road, which currently serves an existing real estate office and a residential
home. The existing real estate office lies on the western side of the drive while the
residential home lies at the end of the drive. The proposed bank will be located on
the eastern side of the drive across from the real estate office.
Based on the projected vehicle trips that would be generated by the proposed bank,
the intersection of Route 195 (Merrow Road) at Fieldstone Commons and the Site
Drive was identified as the location most likely to be impacted by the proposed
project and represents the full study area.
To assess existing traffic conditions in the vicinity of the site, manual turning
movement traffic volumes were recorded at the study intersection during the
weekday evening and Saturday midday peak traffic periods in November and
December 2012. These existing traffic volumes were then projected to the year 2013 to
evaluate traffic operating conditions when the proposed bank is fully occupied.
Independent of the proposed development, background traffic growth was
conservatively added to the existing traffic volumes to establish the future traffic
volume conditions without the proposed development.
The traffic volumes anticipated to be generated by the proposed bank were
forth by the Connecticut Department of Transportation (CTDOT). Based on these
projections, the proposed bank is expected to generate 38 (19 enter, 19 exit) new
vehicle trips during the weekday evening peak hour and 42 (21 enter, 21 exit) new
vehicle trips during the Saturday midday peak hour. These site-generated traffic
Trip generation based on data in the 9
Edition of the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation
Manual; Land Use 912 (Drive-in Bank) was selected for analysis of the proposed bank
volumes were distributed onto the area roadways to forecast the future traffic
Capacity analyses were conducted to assess the quality of traffic flow in the study
area under existing conditions and future conditions with and without the
construction of the proposed development. Based on these capacity analyses, the
intersection of Route 195 at Fieldstone Commons and the Site Drive currently
operates at acceptable levels of service and will continue to operate at acceptable
levels of service under each of the future conditions evaluated.
On-site vehicle queuing at teller windows and the ATM will be accommodated with
one drive-in lane providing access to two (2) drive-in teller positions. Additionally,
one (1) ATM position is located adjacent to the two (2) drive-in teller positions.
Based on recent drive-through queue studies, sufficient on-site queue storage is
available for the drive-in lanes and no vehicle blockages on-site or off-site are
It is therefore the finding of this study that the construction of the proposed bank will
not have an adverse impact on the safety and operating conditions of the
surrounding road network. Furthermore, the proposed site driveway can adequately
Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc. (VHB) has been retained by Simon Konover
Development Corporation to conduct a traffic impact and access study documenting
the potential traffic impacts associated with the construction of a proposed bank in
Tolland, Connecticut. The traffic impact study quantifies both the existing traffic
conditions along area roadways surrounding the site and the projected future traffic
conditions expected with and without the proposed development of the site. This
document provides a detailed description of the study methodology, analysis, and
The proposed development site is an approximately 6.1-acre vacant parcel located on
Route 195 (Merrow Road) approximately 0.1 miles east of I-84 in Tolland,
Connecticut. The site is bounded by a privately owned access drive and a real estate
office to the west, Route 195 to the south and residential private properties to the
north and east. Based on current plans, the proposed site development will consist of
the construction of a 1,973 SF bank with drive-in service.
The site is currently a paved empty lot located along the eastern side of a privately
owned access drive. The existing private driveway approaches Route 195 and the
Fieldstone Commons Drive from the north to form a four legged signal-controlled
intersection. The site access drives along the private drive consist of an entrance only
drive approximately 50 feet north of Route 195 and an exit only drive approximately
165 feet north of Route 195. These access drives are at approximately the same
locations as the current paved access locations to the lot.
The focus of this study was to evaluate the traffic flows and operating conditions on
the roadways and intersections projected to be used by motorists traveling to and
from the proposed development and to quantify the potential traffic impacts on these
The greatest cumulative impacts of project-related traffic are likely to occur during
the weekday evening and Saturday Midday peak hours when commuter and
shopping traffic is highest. As such, traffic operating conditions were analyzed
Based on the projected vehicle trips that would be generated by the proposed bank,
the intersection of Route 195 (Merrow Road) at Fieldstone Commons and the Site
Drive was identified as the location most likely to be impacted by the proposed
project and represents the full study area.
The proposed project location and study intersection are depicted on Figure 1.
Evaluation of the traffic impacts associated with the proposed development requires
a thorough understanding of the existing roadway system in the vicinity of the site.
The existing conditions observed in the study area include roadway and intersection
geometry (including existing traffic control), traffic volumes, and vehicle accident
history. This information is provided in the following section.
Merrow Road (Route 195) is a two-lane (one lane in each direction) rural principal
arterial roadway with auxiliary turning lanes provided at major intersections and
commercial driveways. The posted speed limit on Merrow Road is 35 miles per hour
within the study area. Land use along Merrow Road consists of a mix of residential

text.b: Fieldstone Commons Drive and Site Drive

page.text: Merrow Road (Route 195) is intersected by the Fieldstone Commons Drive from the
south and a privately owned access drive from the north to form a four-legged
signalized intersection. The eastbound Merrow Road approach consists of an
exclusive right turn lane and a shared through/left turn lane. The westbound
Merrow Road approach consists of an exclusive left turn lane and a shared
through/right turn lane. The southbound private access drive approach consists of a
single multi-use lane. The northbound Fieldstone Commons Drive approach consists
of exclusive right-turn and shared through/left turn lanes. All turning movements at
the intersection are controlled by an actuated uncoordinated traffic control signal.
Pedestrians are accommodated with concurrent pedestrian phases and crosswalks
across the eastern Merrow Road crossing and the Fieldstone Commons Drive
An aerial view of the Merrow Road at Fieldstone Commons Drive / Site Drive

text.b: Aerial view of Merrow Road (Route 195)at Old Stratford Road / Commerce Drive

page.text: As part of the existing conditions analysis, accident history at each of the study
intersections was obtained from the Connecticut Department of Transportation
(CTDOT) Bureau of Planning and Research, which compiles records of accident data
reported by investigating police authorities. It should be noted that only accidents
that result in death, injury, or property damage in excess of $1,000 are required to be
reported. The accident history obtained from the CTDOT records covered the most
recent three-year period available, from January 2007 through December 2009.
According to the CTDOT accident records mentioned above, the intersection of
Merrow Road (Route 195) at Fieldstone Commons Drive/Site Drive experienced a
Image obtained from Google Earth: http://earth.google.com/, accessed 12/4/12
very low accident rate, as only 3 total accidents were reported during the three-year
analysis period (2007 to 2009). An injury occurred in 1 (33-percent) of these accidents,
while the remaining 2 (67-percent) consisted of property damage only. The most
common collision types were turning-intersecting paths accidents, which accounted
for 2 (67-percent) of the total reported accidents during the analysis period.
Detailed accident data obtained from CTDOT for the study intersection is included in
To assess existing traffic conditions in the vicinity of the site, peak hour manual
turning movement traffic volumes and pedestrian counts were recorded at the study
intersections in November and December 2012. The counts were recorded during a
typical weekday evening (4pm – 6pm) and Saturday midday (11am – 1pm) peak
traffic periods. These traffic volumes were used directly to establish the existing peak
hour traffic volume networks depicted on Figure 2.
Additionally, the CTDOT Traffic Monitoring & Data Analysis group records traffic
volumes on various State roads and publishes the data for public use. CTDOT
recorded daily traffic volumes along Route 195 in the vicinity of the site in 2011.
Based on the CTDOT recorded daily traffic volumes record, Route 195 carried
approximately 17,600 vehicles daily in 2011 in the vicinity of the proposed site.
In order to evaluate traffic conditions when the proposed bank is fully occupied,
existing traffic volumes in the study area were projected to the year 2013. The
projected traffic volumes on the roadway network under 2013 No-Build conditions
were assumed to include all existing traffic and new traffic resulting from
background traffic growth, independent of the proposed development. The projected
traffic volumes on the roadway network under 2013 Build conditions were assumed
to include the anticipated project site-generated traffic volumes in addition to the
Traffic growth is typically a function of the expected land development, economic
activity and changes in demographics in the region. To estimate the rate at which
traffic can be expected to grow during the study period, both historical growth and
planned area developments were reviewed and carefully considered.
Based on discussions with the Town of Tolland Planning and Zoning Department, it
was determined that there were no significant developments planned within the
vicinity of the proposed project. CTDOT currently plans to widen Route 195 in the
future in order to better accommodate vehicle demand during University of
Connecticut sporting events, however, those improvements are not expected to begin
As recommended by the CTDOT forecasting unit, a 1.5 percent per year traffic
growth rate was utilized to account for general increases in population and
background growth not associated with nearby planned developments. This annual
growth rate was applied to the existing traffic count data over the one-year
development period to forecast the 2013 No-Build traffic volume networks, which
The anticipated project site-generated trips were projected based on guidelines set
forth by CTDOT and data provided by the 9
Transportation Engineers (ITE) Trip Generation Manual. This widely used reference
manual provides trip generation rates for various land uses based on traffic count
data collected at similar sites. Land use 912 (Drive-in Bank) was selected for analysis
A summary of the trip generation projections for the proposed bank is presented in
Table 1. As indicated in this table, the proposed bank is projected to generate 48 (24
enter, 24 exit) vehicle trips during the weekday afternoon peak hour and 52 (26 enter,
26 exit) vehicle trips during the Saturday midday peak hour.
Based on ITE Land Use Code (LUC) 912 (Drive-in Bank) and 1.973 kSF
Traffic volumes expressed in vehicles per hour
It should be noted that not all of the traffic attracted to the site will be new traffic on
the study area roadways. A portion of vehicle trips generated by banks is classified
as “pass-by” traffic. Pass-by traffic consists of vehicles already on the roadway that
are attracted to a site when passing through the area. The primary destination of this
traffic is elsewhere and the primary trip will be resumed following a stop at the
proposed bank. In accordance with CTDOT guidelines, the lesser of the following is
to be applied as pass-by trips: 20 percent of total site generated trips, or 10 percent of
existing adjacent street traffic. A pass-by trip rate of 20 percent of total site generated
trips was utilized for the proposed site as it is the lesser of the two alternatives.
According to data contained in the ITE Trip Generation Handbook, the average pass-
by rate for similar banks during the weekday afternoon peak hours is 47%, and
observed as high as 64%. Utilizing the average pass-by rate would forecast
significantly less new vehicle trips added to the roadway by the proposed bank.
Therefore, the 20% pass-by rate assumed for the proposed bank should be considered
A summary of the trip generation projections for the proposed development is
presented in Table 2. As indicated in this table, the proposed bank is projected to
generate 38 (19 enter, 19 exit) new primary trips during the weekday evening peak
hour, and 42 (21 enter, 21 exit) new primary vehicle trips during the Saturday
Based on ITE Land Use Code (LUC) 912 (Drive-in Bank) and 1.973 kSF
Assumes a 20% Pass-By Traffic Rate, calculated using ITE methodology.
Traffic volumes expressed in vehicles per hour
The directional distribution of traffic approaching and departing banks is typically a
function of population densities, the location of employment, existing travel patterns,
and the efficiency and limitations of the existing roadway system. Trips made from
and to the proposed bank during the weekday evening and Saturday midday peak
traffic periods are expected to predominantly follow existing travel patterns along
The projected directional distribution of trips to and from the proposed bank is
summarized in Table 3 and depicted on Figure 4.
The new trips generated by the proposed bank were assigned to the area roadways
based on the trip distribution pattern presented in the table above, and the resulting
site-generated traffic volumes are depicted on Figure 5. These site-generated traffic
volumes were added to the 2013 No-Build peak hour traffic volume networks to
establish the 2013 Build peak hour traffic volume networks, which are depicted on
To assess the quality of traffic flow in the study area during the peak periods,
intersection capacity analyses were conducted for existing, 2013 No-Build (without
the proposed development), and 2013 Build (with the proposed development) traffic
volume conditions. The following section summarizes the methods of capacity
analyses used in this study and documents the results.
The intersection capacity analyses were conducted based on the evaluation criteria
contained in the 2000 Highway Capacity Manual
HCM, intersection performance is influenced by a number of factors, including:
traffic demand; lane configurations; lane widths; turning restrictions; roadway
grades; and signal phasing and timing settings for signalized intersections. The
existing physical roadway characteristics and signal phasing and timing settings at
the signalized study intersections were determined by collecting field measurements
and reviewing the current traffic control signal plan provided by the Connecticut
software (Version 7) was used to model the study intersections based on
the parameters mentioned above. Synchro software is widely used by traffic
engineering professionals and is consistent with the procedures in the HCM.
Capacity analyses results are reported using a variety of performance measures,
including “Level of Service” (LOS). The level of service designation is an index based
on the average control delay experienced by a vehicle traveling through the
intersection. Similar to a report card, LOS designations are letter based, ranging from
A to F, with LOS A representing the best operating condition (lowest vehicle delays)
and LOS F representing the worst operating condition (highest vehicle delays).
LOS is reported differently for signalized and unsignalized intersections. For
signalized intersections, the analysis considers the operation of all traffic entering the
intersection, and the LOS can be reported for individual turning movements,
approaches, or for the intersection as a whole. For unsignalized intersections with
Highway Capacity manual 2000; Transportation Research Board, National Research Council, Washington, DC (2000).
Source: Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc. using Synchro 7.0 software.
BOLD represents queue exceeding storage capacity.
On-site vehicle queuing at teller windows and the ATM will be accommodated with
one drive-in lane providing access to two (2) drive-in teller positions. Additionally,
one (1) ATM position is served by one bypass lane and located adjacent to the two (2)
Based on recent drive-through queue studies, included in the Appendix, total
anticipated queue lengths will be less than approximately 8 vehicles. The current site
plan provides total storage for approximately 9 vehicles. Therefore, sufficient on-site
queue storage is available for the drive-in lanes and no vehicle blockages on-site or
stop-control on the side street approaches, such as the site driveway, the analysis
assumes that through and right-turning movements on the main street are
unimpeded by side street traffic. As such, LOS is reported only for left-turns from the
main street and for all movements from the side street; the overall intersection LOS is
The capacity analyses indicate that the signalized intersection of Merrow Road
(Route 195) at Fieldstone Commons and the Site Drive currently operates at level-of-
service ‘D’ during the weekday afternoon peak period and level-of-service ‘B’ during
the Saturday midday peak period. Vehicle delays are not expected to increase
significantly in the future, as the level-of-service for all peaks under the 2013 No-
Build and Build conditions remain unchanged. Therefore, the additional traffic
generated by the proposed bank has minimal impact on vehicle delay.
The results of the intersection capacity analyses are summarized in Table 4.

text.b: LOS Delay v/c LOS Delay v/c

page.text: Source: Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc. using Synchro 7.0 software.
2 Average vehicle delay in seconds per vehicle
In addition to the level of service analysis, Synchro software was utilized to evaluate
the projected maximum vehicle queue lengths at the signalized study intersections
Based on the results of this analysis, the intersection of Merrow Road at Fieldstone
Commons Drive and the Site Drive currently experiences longer vehicle queuing in
the eastbound Merrow Road direction during the weekday evening peak traffic
period. The intersection is expected to continue experiencing longer vehicle queues
in the eastbound direction under the 2013 No-Build and Build conditions, exceeding
the available vehicle storage by approximately 1-2 vehicle lengths.
The results of the queue analysis are summarized in Table 5.
This study has been prepared to evaluate the potential traffic impacts associated with
the construction of a proposed drive-in bank in Tolland, Connecticut. The following
is a summary of the results of this investigation:
Access to the site will be provided via entrance and exit only drives located on
the signalized private driveway located on Merrow Road (Route 195) across
The proposed bank is projected to generate 38 (19 enter, 19 exit) new vehicle
trips during the weekday afternoon peak hour and 42 (21 enter, 21 exit) new
vehicle trips during the Saturday midday peak hour.
The intersection of Merrow Road (Route 195) at Fieldstone Commons Drive and
the Site Drive currently operates at acceptable level-of-service ‘D’ during the
weekday evening peak period and level-of-service ‘B’ during the Saturday
midday peak period and is forecast to continue operating at those levels-of-
service under all study conditions. The proposed bank is not anticipated to have
any significant impact at the intersection and any vehicle delays experienced as
a result of the bank would be minimal.
Based on recent drive-through queue studies, sufficient on-site queue storage is
available for the drive-in lanes and no vehicle blockages on-site or off-site are
It is therefore the finding of this study that the construction of the proposed bank will
not have an adverse impact on the operating conditions of the surrounding road
for Banks and Coffee Shops - Stuecheli
